newsitem.title: UK: Sinn Fein supporters want IRA truce, poll says.
newsitem.headline: Sinn Fein supporters want IRA truce, poll says.

text.p: Most supporters of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Repubican Army (IRA), want the guerrillas to call a new truce in their battle against British rule of Northern Ireland, an opinion poll said on Tuesday.

The Irish News, published in Belfast, said a survey taken two weeks after the IRA killed a British soldier in its first bombing in the province for two years showed that more than seven out of 10 Sinn Fein supporters backed a ceasefire.
The poll of 1,038 people showed "considerable pessimism among all sections of the community over the short-term prospects for peace," the newspaper said in a statement.
The survey found that 94 percent of Northern Ireland's people -- 98 percent of the Protestants and 89 percent of the Catholics -- wanted an end to IRA violence.
"When Sinn Fein supporters were asked if they wanted an immediate ceasefire, 71 per cent said yes and 28 per cent said no," the paper said.
Respondents across the sectarian divide were pessimistic about the prospects that multi-party peace talks, which have made plodding progress since June, would be successful.

Asked if the talks, chaired by former U.S.senator George Mitchell, would reach a settlement acceptable to both Catholic Irish republicans and pro-British Protestants, 61 per cent said this was fairly, or very, unlikely. Only three percent thought it was very likely.
The IRA declared a ceasefire in September 1994 but abandoned it last February, accusing Britain of reneging on a guarantee that Sinn Fein could take part in the all-party talks.
Britain and Ireland insist that the IRA must call off hostilities before Sinn Fein can be admitted to the talks.
